gr.forth.ics.graph.algo.transitivity
Class Transitivity

java.lang.Object
  gr.forth.ics.graph.algo.transitivity.Transitivity

public class Transitivity
extends Object

Transitive closure and reduction algorithms for directed graphs.

Method Detail

acyclicClosure

public static Closure acyclicClosure(InspectableGraph g,
                                     SuccessorSetFactory successorSetFactory)
Creates the transitive Closure of a directed acyclic graph, using the specified factory of successor sets. The time complexity is O(|E|U) where |E| is the number of edges of the graph and U is the average time to merge two successor sets, so the efficiency of the given SuccessorSetFactory is crucially affecting this algorithm. The space complexity also depends directly on the SuccessorSetFactory, and particularly in the space that the generated successor sets use.

To actually create an edge in the graph for every (directly or indirectly) connected pair of nodes, materialize the closure in the graph by Transitivity.materialize(g, closure).

Parameters:
g - the directed acyclic graph to create the transitive closure of
successorSetFactory - the factory of successor sets
Returns:
the closure of the graph
See Also:
SuccessorSetFactory, materialize(Graph, Closure)

acyclicReduction

public static void acyclicReduction(Graph g,
                                    PathFinder pathFinder)
Creates the transitive reduction of a directed acyclic graph, using a pathFinder object to check whether two arbitrary nodes of the specified graph are connected via some path. The given graph is directly modified (by deleting all edges but those belonging to the transitive reduction).

The time complexity of this algorithm is O(|E|P), where |E| is the number of edges and P is the time complexity of a single pathFinder invocation.

Parameters:
g - the directed acyclic graph to create the transitive reduction of
pathFinder - an object that can answer whether two nodes are connected via some path

materialize

public static void materialize(Graph g,
                               Closure closure)
Translates a specified transitive closure to edges in a graph, that is, after this method every node of the graph has at least one edge to each node belonging to each successor set, as defined by the given closure.

Parameters:
g - the graph in which to materialize the closure
closure - the closure to materialize

acyclicClosureSweep

public static void acyclicClosureSweep(InspectableGraph g,
                                       SuccessorSetFactory successorSetFactory,
                                       Transitivity.SuccessorsListener listener)
Sweeps the graph in reverse-topological order (i.e. starting with nodes with zero out-degree, and ending at nodes with zero in-degree), creates on-the-fly the successor set for each node, notifies the provided Transitivity.SuccessorsListener to do arbitrary processing when the complete successor set is available for each node, and then discards the successor sets when they are no longer needed. This method is more memory-efficient than acyclicClosure(InspectableGraph, SuccessorSetFactory) since it only stores successor sets for the duration they are needed, and can be used by providing a SuccessorsListener that processes the successor sets.

Consider for example the graph [A-->B-->C]. The node C will be processed first (through the SuccesorsListener), with an empty successor set, then the node B with a successor set of {C}, and finally the node A with a successor set of {B, C}.

See acyclicClosure(InspectableGraph, SuccessorSetFactory) to understand the time complexity of the algorithm as well as the function of the SuccessorSetFactory.

Parameters:
g - the graph whose nodes to create the successor sets for
successorSetFactory - the factory of successor sets
listener - the listener that processes nodes and their respective successor sets

generalClosure

public static Closure generalClosure(InspectableGraph g,
                                     SuccessorSetFactory successorSetFactory)
